column4: does hibernate (either swusp or an actual acpi hibernate) function correctly with an encrypted hard drive? (specifically, will the hard drive be encrypted after a hibernate, and will the machine hibernate and unhibernate correctly)
suspend-to-RAM works fine with disk encryption
i'm asking about hibernate, not suspend-to-ram
suspend-to-disk won't because the decryption key, normally stored in RAM, gets written to dis, encrypted with itself
well, depending on your setup it may be written to swapspace, but I use random encryption for swap
so when i boot the system again, it won't ask me like it would during a normal boot?  What part of the boot process gets skipped to cause that to happen?
dunno, becuase I haven't used hibernate due to the aforementioned random-encrypted swap
so, you aren't sure?
If you have it save your RAM to a file in the filesystem, in principle it should be possible to prompt you for the passphrase during startup, but I don't know whether that's actually supported

Saving to swap when the swap is random-encrypted is definitely impossible; the key in that case is not known to you, and stored only in RAM, so writing it to swapspace encrypted with that key (and erasing it from RAM) makes it unrecoverable

does hibernate (either swusp or an actual acpi hibernate) function correctly with an encrypted hard drive? (specifically, will the hard drive be encrypted after a hibernate, and will the machine hibernate and unhibernate correctly)
hibernating certainly won't decrypt the drive
but you have to make sure you don't save the RAM somewhere unprotected (such as an unencrypted swap partition) since it contains the key
? that doesn't make sense
you'd asked whether the drive will be encrypted after a hibernate
If it was encrypted before the hibernate, it'll still be encrypted afterward
but if you're not careful you might expose the key
